newsitem.title: POLAND: Polish bank BGZ pre-tax at PLN 348.4 mln Q1-Q3.
newsitem.headline: Polish bank BGZ pre-tax at PLN 348.4 mln Q1-Q3.

text.p: Poland's Bank Gospodarki Zywnosciowej SA (BGZ) made a pre-tax profit of 348.4 million zlotys over the first three quarters this year, the bank's finance director said on Wednesday.
"We think it's a good result," Michal Fogtman told Reuters.

This year, the bank, which made a 235 million zloty first-half pre-tax profit, is required to submit monthly earnings reports as part of its restructuring agreement with the central bank and the finance ministry.

Last year BGZ, as an unlisted bank, published only an annual earnings report, making a net profit of 187 million zlotys and a pre-tax profit of 374 million zlotys. It plans a pre-tax profit of 411 million zlotys for all of 1996.

The bank, which lost 3.1 billion zlotys over the first five years of Poland's economic reforms starting in 1989, pays no income tax as part of the agreement and pays a one-time year-end tax on interest on government restructuring bonds.
Fogtman said interest revenue over three quarters was at 1.3 billion zlotys, up from 831.6 million zlotys after the first half.
He said the bank's own funds had decreased to 1.3 billion zlotys from 1.6 billion zlotys largely as a result of covering losses made over the unprofitable five-year period.
"It's possible that we'll cover the losses from recent years over the next two years," Fogtman said.
BGZ groups some 1,500 small farming cooperative banks, many of which ran into difficulties following a credit boom at the start of Poland's economic transition.
